name: Jerusalem Temple
shortDescription: The sacred Temple complex on Mount Moriahâ€”site of Solomon's Temple, Herod's Temple, and pivotal events in Jewish, Christian, and Islamic history
fullDescription: The Jerusalem Temple was the central sanctuary of ancient Israelite and Jewish worship, built on Mount Moriah where Abraham offered Isaac and where God's presence (Shekhinah) dwelt among Israel. The First Temple, built by King Solomon c. 957 BCE, housed the Ark of the Covenant in the Holy of Holies and was destroyed by Nebuchadnezzar in 586 BCE. After the Babylonian Exile, the Second Temple was built c. 516 BCE and later magnificently expanded by Herod the Great. This Second Temple witnessed Jesus' ministry, including his teaching in the Temple courts, his cleansing of the money-changers, and his prophecy of its destruction. According to church tradition, James the Less (or James the Just) was martyred at the Temple pinnacle c. 62 CE, thrown down and beaten with a fuller's club. The Romans destroyed the Second Temple in 70 CE, leaving only the Western Wall. The Temple Mount now holds the Dome of the Rock and Al-Aqsa Mosque, sacred to Islam as the site of Muhammad's Night Journey. The Temple remains central to Jewish eschatology, Christian typology (Jesus as the new Temple), and interfaith tensions over sacred space.

etymology.origin: Hebrew 'Beit HaMikdash' means 'House of Holiness' or 'Sanctuary.' Arabic 'Haram al-Sharif' means 'Noble Sanctuary.' Greek 'hieron' (sacred precinct) and 'naos' (inner sanctuary) used in New Testament.

mythologyContexts.usage: Central sanctuary of Israelite worship; dwelling place of God's presence; site of sacrificial system; focus of pilgrimage festivals
mythologyContexts.symbolism: The Temple represented God's dwelling among Israel (Exodus 25:8). The Holy of Holies, containing the Ark, was the earthly throne room of YHWH. The sacrificial system mediated divine-human relationship. After 70 CE, synagogue prayer and Torah study replaced Temple sacrifice, but longing for Temple restoration remains central to Jewish eschatology.

textReferences.context: Temple construction, dedication, rebuilding, and pilgrimage

mythologyContexts.usage: Site of Jesus' presentation as infant; his teaching and conflicts; his prophecy of destruction; symbol of his body (John 2:19-21); typology for church as 'temple of Holy Spirit'
mythologyContexts.symbolism: Jesus identified himself as the new Temple (John 2:19-21). The torn Temple veil signifies direct access to God through Christ's sacrifice (Hebrews 10:19-20). The church becomes the 'temple of the living God' (2 Corinthians 6:16). The Temple's destruction in 70 CE was seen as fulfillment of Jesus' prophecy and vindication of the new covenant.

textReferences.context: Jesus in the Temple; Temple typology; New Covenant access

mythologyContexts.usage: Site of Prophet Muhammad's Night Journey (Isra) and Ascension (Mi'raj); third holiest site in Islam; location of Al-Aqsa Mosque and Dome of the Rock
mythologyContexts.symbolism: The Temple Mount is the destination of Muhammad's miraculous Night Journey from Mecca (Surah 17:1). From the Foundation Stone (beneath the Dome of the Rock), Muhammad ascended through the heavens. The site connects Islam to the prophetic tradition of Abraham, Solomon, and Jesus, while establishing Jerusalem as Islam's third holiest city.
